introduction.p: In this activity we approximate the values of several different alternating series using the Alternating Series Estimation Theorem.

statement.p: Use the fact that \sin(x) = x - \frac{1}{3!}x^3 + \frac{1}{5!}x^5 - \cdots to estimate \sin(1) to within 0.0001. Do so without entering \sin(1) on a computational device. After you find your estimate, enter \sin(1) on a computational device and compare the results.

answer.p: \sin(1) \approx 1 - \frac{1}{3!} + \frac{1}{5!} - \frac{1}{7!} = \frac{4241}{5040} = 0.8414682539682539\ldots , and this approximation has error at most \frac{1}{9!} \approx 0.00000276.

solution.p:
Since \sin(x) = x - \frac{1}{3!}x^3 + \frac{1}{5!}x^7 - \cdots, we have
\sin(1) = 1 - \frac{1}{3!}1^3 + \frac{1}{5!}1^7 - \frac{1}{7!}1^9 + \cdots
so that, for example,
\sin(1) \approx 1 - \frac{1}{3!} + \frac{1}{5!} - \frac{1}{7!} . This approximation has error at most \frac{1}{9!} since that's the next term in the sum. Since \frac{1}{9!} \approx 0.00000276, we are even more accurate than required. Note that since \frac{1}{7!} \approx 0.000198, we can't stop after the third term and indeed need the four above. Thus,
\sin(1) \approx 1 - \frac{1}{3!} + \frac{1}{5!} - \frac{1}{7!} = \frac{4241}{5040} = 0.8414682539682539\ldots
If we as a computational device the value of \sin(1), we get \sin(1) = 0.84147098\ldots.

statement.p:
Recall our recent work with \int_0^1 e^{-x^2} \, dx which can be expressed as the series
\int_0^1 e^{-x^2} \, dx = 1 - \frac{1}{3} + \frac{1}{2! \cdot 5} - \frac{1}{3! \cdot 7} + \cdots + \frac{(-1)^n}{n! \cdot (2n+1)} + \cdots . Use this series representation to estimate \int_0^1 e^{-x^2} \, dx to within 0.0001. Then, compare what a computational device reports when you use it to estimate the definite integral.

answer.p:
\int_0^1 e^{-x^2} \, dx \approx 1 - \frac{1}{3} + \frac{1}{2! \cdot 5} - \frac{1}{3! \cdot 7} + \frac{1}{4! \cdot 9} - \frac{1}{5! \cdot 11} + \frac{1}{6! \cdot 13} = \frac{1614779}{2162160} = 0.7468360343\ldots
and this approximation has error at most \frac{1}{7! \cdot 15} = \frac{1}{756600} \approx 0.0000132

solution.p:
Since
\int_0^1 e^{-x^2} \, dx = 1 - \frac{1}{3} + \frac{1}{2! \cdot 5} - \frac{1}{3! \cdot 7} + \cdots + \frac{(-1)^n}{n! \cdot (2n+1)} + \cdots , we can truncate the alternating series to get a good estimate of the integral. We note that \frac{1}{6! \cdot 13} = \frac{1}{9360} = 0.00010683\ldots, and the next term after this one is less than 0.0001, so that
\int_0^1 e^{-x^2} \, dx \approx 1 - \frac{1}{3} + \frac{1}{2! \cdot 5} - \frac{1}{3! \cdot 7} + \frac{1}{4! \cdot 9} - \frac{1}{5! \cdot 11} + \frac{1}{6! \cdot 13} = \frac{1614779}{2162160} = 0.7468360343\ldots
A computational device reports that \int_0^1 e^{-x^2} \, dx \approx 0.746824.

statement.p: Find the Taylor series for \cos(x^2) and then use the Taylor series and to estimate the value of \int_0^1 \cos(x^2) \, dx to within 0.0001. Compare your result to what a computational device reports when you use it to estimate the definite integral.

answer.p:
\int_0^1 \cos(x^2) \, dx \approx 1 - \frac{1}{5 \cdot 2!} + \frac{1}{9 \cdot 4!} - \frac{1}{13 \cdot 6!} = \frac{25399}{28080} = 0.904522792022792022792\ldots
and this approximation has error at most \frac{1}{17 \cdot 8!} = \frac{1}{685440} = 0.0000014589 \ldots .

solution.p:
We find that
\cos(x^2) = 1 - \frac{1}{2!}x^4 + \frac{1}{4!}x^8 - \frac{1}{6!}x^{12} + \cdots , so
\int_0^1 \cos(x^2) \, dx = \left. x - \frac{1}{5 \cdot 2!}x^5 + \frac{1}{9 \cdot 4!}x^9 - \frac{1}{13 \cdot 6!}x^{13} + \cdots \right|_0^1 . Thus,
\int_0^1 \cos(x^2) \, dx = 1 - \frac{1}{5 \cdot 2!} + \frac{1}{9 \cdot 4!} - \frac{1}{13 \cdot 6!} + \cdots . Since \frac{1}{13 \cdot 6!} = \frac{1}{9360} \approx 0.0001068, the next term (\frac{1}{17 \cdot 8!} = \frac{1}{685440} = 0.0000014589 \ldots ) is (much) less than 0.0001 and thus we have
\int_0^1 \cos(x^2) \, dx \approx 1 - \frac{1}{5 \cdot 2!} + \frac{1}{9 \cdot 4!} - \frac{1}{13 \cdot 6!} = \frac{25399}{28080} = 0.904522792022792022792\ldots . A computational device reports that \int_0^1 \cos(x^2) \, dx \approx 0.914524.

statement.p:
Recall we know that if |x| \lt 1, then
\ln(1+x) = x - \frac{1}{2}x^2 + \frac{1}{3}x^3 - \cdots + (-1)^{n-1} \frac{1}{n} x^n + \cdots . What happens if x = 1?

Explain why the series 1 - \frac{1}{2} \cdot 1^2 + \frac{1}{3} \cdot 1^3 - \cdots + (-1)^{n-1} \frac{1}{n} \cdot 1^n + \cdots must converge and estimate its sum to within 0.01. What is the exact sum of this series?

answer.p:
The alternating series
1 - \frac{1}{2} \cdot 1^2 + \frac{1}{3} \cdot 1^3 - \cdots + (-1)^{n-1} \frac{1}{n} \cdot 1^n + \cdots
converges by the Alternating Series Theorem, and its exact sum is \ln(2).

solution.p:
If we let x = 1 in the series
x - \frac{1}{2}x^2 + \frac{1}{3}x^3 - \cdots + (-1)^{n-1} \frac{1}{n} x^n + \cdots , we see that we get the converging alternating series
1 - \frac{1}{2} \cdot 1^2 + \frac{1}{3} \cdot 1^3 - \cdots + (-1)^{n-1} \frac{1}{n} \cdot 1^n + \cdots
by the Alternating Series Theorem. Indeed, since \ln(1+x) = x - \frac{1}{2}x^2 + \frac{1}{3}x^3 - \cdots + (-1)^{n-1} \frac{1}{n} x^n + \cdots, it follows that the exact sum of the series
1 - \frac{1}{2} \cdot 1^2 + \frac{1}{3} \cdot 1^3 - \cdots + (-1)^{n-1} \frac{1}{n} \cdot 1^n + \cdots
is \ln(2):
\ln(2) = 1 - \frac{1}{2} \cdot 1^2 + \frac{1}{3} \cdot 1^3 - \cdots + (-1)^{n-1} \frac{1}{n} \cdot 1^n + \cdots . This is an example of a Taylor series that converges at one of the endpoints of the interval of convergence.
